questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Transduction of sound (mechanical energy to electrical impulses) is done by the sensory system of the cochlea. It is not a function of the middle ear.

The functions of the middle ear are:

  • Conduction of sound through impedance matching or transformer action
  • Protection of inner ear
  • Amplification of sound intensity

questions.text: What is the lever ratio of the ear ossicles?
questions.solution:
The lever ratio of the ear ossicles is 1.3:1.

The handle of the malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of the incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.

questions.text: The effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane is much larger than the area of stapes footplate. Which of the following is the most accurate value of the average ratio between the two?
questions.solution:
The ratio of effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane to the area of footplate of stapes (areal ratio) is 17:1 .

Effective vibratory area of TM = 55 mm2

Footplate area = 3.2 mm2 

Areal ratio = Effective vibratory area of tympanic membrane ÷ stapes footplate area

questions.text: What is the transformer ratio of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The transformer ratio of the middle ear is 22:1

The middle ear has to conduct sound waves from a low impedance tympanic membrane to a high impedance oval window. This is done by matching their impedances. It is called transforming action.

Transformer ratio =Areal ratio × Lever ratio

questions.text: What is the natural resonance of the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
The natural resonance of the tympanic membrane is 800 – 1600 Hz.

Aging causes a decrease in the external ear resonance amplitude due to the collapse of the external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane becoming senile. This factor has to be considered to appropriately diagnose hearing loss and in the selection of hearing aids.

Natural resonance and efficiency of auditory apparatus:

  • External auditory canal- 3000 Hz
  • Tympanic membrane- 800–1600 Hz
  • Middle ear- 800 Hz
  • Ossicular chain- 500–2000 Hz

questions.text: Which of the following factors do not contribute to the impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear?

choices.text: Lever action of ossicles providing mechanical advantage of 1.3
Phase difference between the oval and round windows
Relatively large area of the tympanic membrane compared to  stapes footplate
More movements at the centre of the tympanic membrane than at periphery

questions.solution:
Movements of the tympanic membrane are more at the periphery than at the center, where the malleus handle is attached. This is called the curved membrane effect and it contributes to the impedance matching mechanism of the ear.

Other factors responsible for the impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear are:

  • The lever action of the ossicles- handle of malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.
  • Hydraulic action of the tympanic membrane- relatively large area of the tympanic membrane compared to the stapes footplate.
  • The medial side of the tympanic membrane is multiphasic whereas the lateral side is uniphasic. This provides a multiple integrated multilever mechanical advantage.

questions.text: Who proposed the travelling wave theory of cochlear mechanics?
questions.solution:
The traveling wave theory was proposed by von Békésy.

It states that a sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment.

Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

questions.text: What is the endocochlear potential recorded from the scala media?
questions.solution: Endocochlear potential is a direct current (DC) potential recorded from scala media. It is +80 mV and is generated from the stria vascularis by Na+/K+-ATPase pump and provides a source of energy for cochlear transduction. It is present at rest and does not require a sound stimulus.

questions.text: You are an intern performing the tuning fork tests on a patient who presented to the ENT OPD with complaints of decreased hearing in the left ear. Which of the following tuning forks is most commonly used for the routine clinical assessment for such patients?
questions.solution:
A tuning fork of 512 Hz is most commonly used for routine clinical assessment in ENT. 

Tuning forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time and are thus not routinely preferred.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with hearing loss in the right ear. A 512 Hz tuning fork is used, which highlights the Rinne test is positive bilaterally. What is the likely inference?

choices.text: Air conduction is better than bone conduction
Bone conduction is better than air conduction
Air conduction is equal to bone conduction
Bone conduction is worse than that of examiner's

questions.solution:
Rinne test is positive when the air conduction (AC) is longer or louder than bone conduction (BC).

questions.text: What should be the minimum hearing loss in a patient for the Rinne test to be negative?
questions.solution:
The minimum hearing loss for the Rinne test to be negative is 15-20dB.

Negative Rinne (BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with a conductive type of hearing loss, a negative Rinne test with a 512 Hz tuning fork indicates a minimum air-bone gap of?
questions.solution:
The negative Rinne test for 512 Hz indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 30 dB. 

Rinne’s test is a tuning fork test performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, and 1024 Hz.

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC) i.e. AC>BC. The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. 

As a general prediction, a negative Rinne's test with any tuning fork frequency suggests a minimum hearing loss of at least 15 - 20 dB.The table below indicates a rough minimum air-bone gap for negative Rinne's test at different frequencies: 

Negative Rinne test Minimum air-bone gap
256 Hz 15 dB
512 Hz 30 dB
1024 Hz 45 dB

A prediction of the air-bone gap can be made based on the combination of tuning fork tests of 256, 512, and 1024 Hz:

  • A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 20-30 dB.
  • A Rinne test negative for 256 and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 30-45 dB.
  • A Rinne test negative for 256, 512, and 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 45-60 dB.

questions.text: You are a first-year resident performing the tuning fork tests on the following patients to assess their hearing loss. Which one of them will you expect to have a positive Rinne test?

choices.text: A child with chronic suppurative otitis media
An adolescent man with impacted wax

questions.solution:
A positive Rinne test is seen in presbycusis, which is a type of sensorineural deafness.

A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is longer than bone conduction, as seen in normal ear and sensorineural deafness.

A negative Rinne test indicates that bone conduction is longer than air conduction, as seen in conditions causing in conductive deafness such as chronic suppurative otitis media, impacted wax, and otosclerosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man diagnosed with Ménière's disease presented with severe unilateral hearing loss. Which of the following would be the most likely finding on performing the Rinne test on this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with Ménière's disease present with a sensorineural type of hearing loss. A false negative Rinne test is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

The patient doesn’t respond to air conduction but is able to hear when a tuning fork is placed over the mastoid process i.e. bone conduction > air conduction. Hence reported as negative. This is a false negative because this response to bone conduction is from the opposite ear due to transcranial transmission of sound.

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss as a consequence of untreated suppurative labyrinthitis and Rinne's test is a false negative in this case.

Initially, the patient had a positive fistula test, which implies that the labyrinth is still functioning. Rinne's test is positive which could be due to normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss.

Currently, the patient has a negative fistula test which implies that the labyrinth is dead. This is an example of severe sensorineural hearing loss and here, Rinne test is a false negative.

If intermittent pressure applied to the external ear produces vertigo and nystagmus, it is a positive fistula test. The pressure changes in the external ear are transmitted to the labyrinth. This is suggestive of abnormal communication between the middle ear and the inner ear.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the test being performed on a patient by an ENT resident as shown below?

choices.text: It is lateralized to worse ear in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome
It is heard equally on both sides in normal individual
It is lateralized towards better ear in cochlear otosclerosis
It is lateralized towards worse ear in Ménière’s disease

questions.solution:
The image shows the Weber test being performed. Ménière’s disease causes sensorineural hearing loss and hence Weber test is lateralized towards the better ear. 

In Weber's test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.

It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

Option A: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the worse ear.

Option B: In normal individuals, the sound is heard equally in both ears. So Weber is not lateralized. 

Option C: Cochlear otosclerosis causes sensorineural deafness, whereas stapedial otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the better ear in case of cochlear otosclerosis.

questions.text: A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal of the patient by pressing the tragus inwards to examine the effect of occlusion on hearing. What is the test being performed here?
questions.solution:
Bing test is being performed in the given clinical scenario.

It is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on hearing.  A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid. The examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing the tragus inwards.

Bing positive: A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open.

Bing negative: A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change.

questions.text: A young female diagnosed with otosclerosis presented to the ENT OPD with worsening hearing loss. Which of the following will be the most likely observation on the Bing test?

choices.text: Hears louder when canal is occluded
Hears softer when canal is occluded
The test is said to be positive

questions.solution:
The patient diagnosed with otosclerosis will have a conductive type of hearing loss and will appreciate no change in the Bing test. Here, the Bing test is said to be negative. 

Bing test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on hearing.  A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid. The examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing on the tragus inwards.

Bing positive: A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open.

Bing negative: A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change.

questions.text: In which of the following diseases would you find a negative Gelle's test?
questions.solution:
Gelle’s test is negative in otosclerosis. 

It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound (positive Gelle's test). But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound (negative Gelle's test).

It was once a popular test to find out stapes fixation in otosclerosis but has now been superseded by tympanometry.

questions.text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness.

Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates right-sided conductive deafness or left-sided sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne's test is positive on both the ears, conductive deafness can be ruled out and hence, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected?
questions.solution:
Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) damages the outer hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.

NIHL occurs after chronic exposure to less intense sounds. The damage caused by noise trauma depends on the frequency of noise (frequency of 2000 to 3000 Hz causes more damage) intensity, duration of the noise, and preexisting ear disease.

The audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss shows a typical notch at 4000Hz both for air and bone conduction known as acoustic dip/boiler's notch. Patients at this stage complain of high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty hearing in noisy surroundings. Pre-employment and annual audiograms for persons working at places where noise is above 85 dB (A) help in the early detection of NIHL. 

The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz. Below 20 Hz, the vibrations are infra-audible, and above 20,000 Hz, they are ultra-sonic. Pure tone audiometry can detect only up to 8000 Hz.

Extended high-frequency audiometry is recommended for early detection of hearing loss, as it can identify hearing impairments before the frequencies necessary for speech comprehension are affected. Distortion product otoacoustic emissions is a more sensitive tool than conventional audiometry, particularly in children under 5 years old for early detection of hearing loss. 

A noise of 90 dB(A) SPL (acceptable noise levels, sound pressure level), 8 hours a day for 5 days per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour. As per WHO, 85 dB(A) is considered the highest safe exposure level up to a maximum of 8 hours. 

The silence zone extends to a distance of 100 meters around the premises of hospitals, nursing homes, educational institutions, and courts.

Permissible limits of noise as per the noise pollution (Regulation and Control) rules: 

Zone/Area Day (6 am to 10 pm) limits in dB(A) Night (10 pm to 6 am) limits in dB(A)
Industrial 75 70
Commercial 65 55
Residential 55 45
Silence 50 40

Noise levels are measured in dB(A), which prioritizes middle-range frequencies for assessing noise-induced hearing loss while giving less weightage to low and high frequencies.

The image below shows an acoustic dip at 4000Hz: 

Other options: 

Option A: Crista ampullaris is a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium in the ampullated end of semicircular ducts.

Option B: Macula is the sensory epithelium of the utricle

Option C: Cupula is a gelatinous mass extending from the surface of the crista (peripheral receptor located in the ampullated end of semicircular ducts) to the ceiling of the ampulla, into which project the cilia of sensory hair cells. 

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.
